- Clear reasoning for each choice
- Icons imported and ready to use in AppSidebar

title: Set up navigation menu structure in AppSidebar
description:
Build the navigation menu structure using shadcn sidebar components for Dashboard, Companies, and Contacts.

LEARNING GOALS:
- Understand shadcn's sidebar component composition pattern
- Learn how to structure semantic navigation with proper accessibility
- Practice component hierarchy: SidebarGroup → SidebarMenu → SidebarMenuItem
- Understand the role of SidebarGroupLabel for menu organization

COMPONENT STRUCTURE TO BUILD:
AppSidebar
├─ SidebarHeader (branding/logo area)
├─ SidebarContent
│  └─ SidebarGroup
│     ├─ SidebarGroupLabel (e.g., 'Navigation' or 'Main Menu')
│     └─ SidebarMenu
│        ├─ SidebarMenuItem (Dashboard)
│        │  └─ SidebarMenuButton
│        ├─ SidebarMenuItem (Companies)
│        │  └─ SidebarMenuButton
│        └─ SidebarMenuItem (Contacts)
│           └─ SidebarMenuButton
└─ SidebarFooter (user profile area - placeholder for now)

KEY CONCEPTS:
- SidebarGroup: Groups related navigation items
- SidebarGroupLabel: Optional header text for the group
- SidebarMenu: Unordered list wrapper for menu items
- SidebarMenuItem: List item wrapper
- SidebarMenuButton: Interactive button element with built-in styling

TASKS:
1. Review the sidebar component structure in components/ui/sidebar.tsx:331-674
2. Import necessary sidebar components into AppSidebar.tsx
3. Add SidebarGroupLabel with text like 'Navigation' or leave it out
4. Create SidebarMenu with three SidebarMenuItem children
5. Add SidebarMenuButton to each item with placeholder text
6. Test the visual layout in the browser

CHECKPOINT:
You'll know you're done when:
- Three menu items appear in the sidebar
- The component tree follows the proper hierarchy
- No TypeScript errors
- The sidebar renders and items are clickable (no functionality yet)

RESOURCES:
- Review: components/ui/sidebar.tsx:381-468 (Group, Menu, MenuItem components)
- shadcn sidebar docs: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/sidebar
- Previous session notes: docs/sessions/2026-02-09-sidebar-layout-foundation.md

title: Make menu items clickable with Next.js Link
description: Convert SidebarMenuButton components to use Next.js Link for navigation. LEARNING GOALS: - Understand the asChild prop pattern in Radix UI (used by shadcn) - Learn how to compose Link with SidebarMenuButton - Practice client-side navigation in Next.js App Router - Understand the Slot component pattern DEPENDS ON: - crm-build-4lc: Menu structure must exist KEY CONCEPTS: - asChild prop allows SidebarMenuButton to delegate rendering to child - This lets Link handle navigation while SidebarMenuButton provides styling - Slot component merges props from both components - This is a common pattern in shadcn components for composition COMPONENT PATTERN: import Link from 'next/link' Dashboard WHY asChild? - Without asChild: You'd have nested buttons/links (invalid HTML) - With asChild: Link takes the place of button, inheriting all styling - SidebarMenuButton becomes just a style provider TASKS: 1. Import Link from 'next/link' 2. Add asChild prop to each SidebarMenuButton 3. Wrap icon and text in Link component with href prop 4. Set appropriate hrefs: /dashboard, /companies, /contacts 5. Test navigation - clicking should change routes 6. Verify active states update when navigating CHECKPOINT: You'll know you're done when: - Clicking menu items navigates to different routes - Browser URL changes when clicking items - No nested button warnings in console - Active state updates on navigation - Back/forward browser buttons work correctly COMMON PITFALLS: - Forgetting asChild prop (creates nested buttons) - Wrong Link import (next/router vs next/link) - Not wrapping all content in Link (icons/text outside) RESOURCES: - Radix Slot docs: https://www.radix-ui.com/primitives/docs/utilities/slot - Next.js Link: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/components/link - asChild pattern: components/ui/sidebar.tsx:505 (see implementation)

title: Implement active route highlighting for navigation
description:
Add active state styling to navigation items based on current route using Next.js usePathname.

LEARNING GOALS:
- Learn to use Next.js usePathname hook for route detection
- Understand the 'use client' directive and when it's needed
- Practice conditional styling with the isActive prop
- Learn about client-side navigation in App Router

DEPENDS ON:
- crm-build-4lc: Menu structure must exist

KEY CONCEPTS:
- usePathname is a client-side hook (requires 'use client' at top of component)
- SidebarMenuButton has an isActive prop for active states
- Active items get special styling: data-active:bg-sidebar-accent
- Route matching: pathname === '/dashboard' or pathname.startsWith('/companies')

CLIENT VS SERVER COMPONENTS:
AppSidebar needs to be a client component because:
- It uses usePathname (client-side hook)
- It needs to react to route changes
- Add 'use client' directive at the very top of the file

IMPLEMENTATION PATTERN:
'use client'

import { usePathname } from 'next/navigation'

// In component:
const pathname = usePathname()

<SidebarMenuButton isActive={pathname === '/dashboard'}>
  ...
</SidebarMenuButton>

TASKS:
1. Add 'use client' directive to AppSidebar.tsx (first line)
2. Import usePathname from 'next/navigation'
3. Call usePathname hook at top of component
4. Add isActive prop to each SidebarMenuButton
5. Use pathname comparison: pathname === '/dashboard', etc.
6. Test by navigating to different routes (you'll need to create placeholder pages)

CHECKPOINT:
You'll know you're done when:
- Active menu item is visually highlighted
- Clicking different items changes which one is active
- No TypeScript errors with 'use client'
- Active state persists on page refresh
- Only one item is active at a time

EDGE CASES TO CONSIDER:
- Root path ('/') - should it activate dashboard?
- Nested routes (/companies/123) - should use startsWith
- Routes that don't match any menu item

RESOURCES:
- Next.js usePathname: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/functions/use-pathname
- Client Components: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/rendering/client-components
- SidebarMenuButton props: components/ui/sidebar.tsx:492-540

title: Add group label to navigation section
description:
Add a SidebarGroupLabel to provide context for the navigation menu items.

LEARNING GOALS:
- Understand the purpose of group labels in navigation
- Learn when to use vs omit group labels
- Practice semantic HTML structure in navigation

DEPENDS ON:
- crm-build-4lc: Menu structure must exist

KEY CONCEPTS:
- SidebarGroupLabel provides context for grouped menu items
- In collapsed state, group labels automatically hide (opacity-0)
- Optional but improves accessibility and scannability
- Common labels: 'Navigation', 'Main Menu', 'Workspace', or leave blank

COMPONENT PATTERN:
<SidebarGroup>
  <SidebarGroupLabel>Navigation</SidebarGroupLabel>
  <SidebarMenu>
    {/* menu items */}
  </SidebarMenu>
</SidebarGroup>

DESIGN DECISION:
Should you use a label?
- YES: If you'll have multiple groups later (Settings, Admin, etc.)
- NO: If navigation is obvious and you prefer minimal design
- For now: Try both and see what feels better!

TASKS:
1. Import SidebarGroupLabel if not already imported
2. Add SidebarGroupLabel as first child of SidebarGroup
3. Try different label text: 'Navigation', 'Main', or leave it out
4. Test in expanded state - does it help or add noise?
5. Test in collapsed state - it should disappear
6. Make a decision: keep it or remove it

CHECKPOINT:
You'll know you're done when:
- You've tested with and without a label
- You've made a conscious choice based on UX
- The label (if used) appears above menu items
- The label disappears when sidebar collapses

NOTE: This is marked P3 (lower priority) because it's optional polish.
You can skip this if you prefer a cleaner look without labels.

RESOURCES:
- SidebarGroupLabel implementation: components/ui/sidebar.tsx:395-413
- Collapsible behavior: group-data-[collapsible=icon]:-mt-8 group-data-[collapsible=icon]:opacity-0

title: Add branding/logo to sidebar header
description:
Add your CRM application branding, logo, or title to the SidebarHeader section. LEARNING GOALS: - Understand the purpose of SidebarHeader - Practice responsive design for collapsed sidebar states - Learn to balance branding visibility with space efficiency DEPENDS ON: - crm-build-4lc: Menu structure should exist KEY CONCEPTS: - SidebarHeader is the top section of the sidebar - Should contain branding, logo, or app name - Needs to handle collapsed state gracefully - In icon-collapsed state, typically shows just an icon or initials DESIGN OPTIONS: 1. Text only: 'CRM' or 'My CRM' 2. Logo + text: Icon with app name 3. Minimal: Just initials 'CM' or an icon 4. Collapsed state: Just icon or initials RESPONSIVE BEHAVIOR: - Expanded: Full logo + text - Collapsed: Just icon or initials - Use group-data-[collapsible=icon] classes to hide text SUGGESTED PATTERN:
C
My CRM Business Management
TASKS: 1. Decide on your CRM app name 2. Import SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarMenuButton if needed 3. Add content to SidebarHeader 4. Choose between text-only, logo, or icon approach 5. Test in expanded state 6. Test in collapsed state - does it look good? 7. Consider adding Link to '/' for home navigation CHECKPOINT: You'll know you're done when: - Sidebar header shows your branding - Collapsed state shows appropriate minimal branding - It looks professional and polished - Clicking header navigates to home (optional) NOTE: P3 priority - this is polish. The sidebar works without it. You can use a simple text placeholder and enhance it later. RESOURCES: - Check the shadcn sidebar examples for inspiration - SidebarHeader component: components/ui/sidebar.tsx:331-340

title: Design and implement database schema for CRM
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn database schema design and migrations.

TASKS:
1. Design tables for: users, contacts, companies, interactions
2. Choose a migration tool (Drizzle ORM or Prisma recommended)
3. Write your first migration to create tables
4. Add relationships between tables (foreign keys)
5. Run the migration against your Neon database

DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS:
- What fields does a contact need?
- How do contacts relate to companies?
- How will you track interactions/activities?
- What indexes might improve performance?

CHECKPOINT: Your database should have a complete schema with proper relationships.
